title: Add Hello World example for VS Code Copilot instructions functionality
body:
This PR adds a simple "Hello World" example that demonstrates VS Code's Copilot instructions functionality, providing both educational value and test coverage for the automatic instructions system.

## Changes Made

### New Test Case
Added a `hello world copilot-instructions` test in `promptsService.test.ts` that verifies the `ComputeAutomaticInstructions` class correctly processes copilot instruction files. The test creates a minimal workspace scenario with a `.github/copilot-instructions.md` file and confirms it gets automatically detected and included in the chat context.

### Hello World Example
Created a complete example in `examples/hello-world/` containing:

- **`hello-world.js`** - A simple JavaScript file demonstrating basic functionality with proper VS Code copyright headers
- **`.github/copilot-instructions.md`** - Sample copilot instructions that explain the hello world context
- **`README.md`** - Documentation explaining how the example works and how to run it

The example demonstrates how VS Code automatically loads copilot instructions from `.github/copilot-instructions.md` files and makes them available to AI coding assistants through the `ComputeAutomaticInstructions` class.

## Example Usage

```bash
cd examples/hello-world
node hello-world.js
```

Output:
```
Hello World!
Hello, VS Code Copilot!
This example demonstrates VS Code Copilot instructions functionality.
```

## Design Principles

- **Minimal footprint** - Only 4 new files, no modifications to existing code
- **Educational** - Serves as a reference for developers learning about copilot instructions
- **Self-contained** - Complete example with documentation and test coverage
- **Follows guidelines** - Adheres to VS Code coding standards including copyright headers, tabs for indentation, and TypeScript patterns

This example provides a concrete demonstration of how the copilot instructions system works in VS Code, making it easier for developers to understand and utilize this functionality in their own projects.

labels.name: verified
labels.description: Verification succeeded

labels.description: Issue identified as probable candidate for fixing in the next release

body: `authFromGitHubToken()` now calls `fetchCopilotToken()` and `fetchCopilotUserInfo()` in parallel. We need to enable the fallback for `fetchCopilotUserInfo()` too to keep it working.

title: Gemini 2.5 Pro goes in loop in edit2 mode

labels.name: important
labels.description: Issue identified as high-priority

body: ref https://github.com/github/copilot/issues/22920 * configure `"chat.edits2.enabled": true` * use `Edit` mode * use `Gemini 2.5 Pro` * open a python file e.g.: ```py import sys def check_status(service_name): """ Simulate checking the status of a service. Returns "running" for demonstration purposes. """ # In a real application, you might check system services or make network calls here. print(f"Checking status of service: {service_name}") status = "running" print(f"Service '{service_name}' is {status}.") return status def main(): if len(sys.argv) < 2: print("Usage: python status_check.py ") sys.exit(1) service_name = sys.argv[1] check_status(service_name) if __name__ == "__main__": main() ``` * use the prompt "Simplify the layouting- think hard" * :bug: see that it goes in loops: @roblourens It took us a bit to troubleshoot this, is there some kind of experiment going on where `edit2` is turned on only for some part of users?

title: Adopt `IChatEntitlementService` in `chatWidget.ts`

labels.name: debt
labels.description: Code quality issues

body:
Noticed how you rely on context keys to drive logic:

https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/fa6188bc91d2b0f16ce980b62f7fcbbfe100c1ff/src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/browser/chatWidget.ts#L387

A better approach is to use `IChatEntitlementService` that has events for `entitlement` and `sentiment` changes:
* `entitlement: ChatEntitlement.Available` maps to if the user can sign up for free
* `sentiment.installed` maps to installation matters

title: fix: elicitation email validator
body:
<!-- Thank you for submitting a Pull Request. Please:
* Read our Pull Request guidelines:
  https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#pull-requests
* Associate an issue with the Pull Request.
* Ensure that the code is up-to-date with the `main` branch.
* Include a description of the proposed changes and how to test them.
-->
This pull request fixes a bug in the email validation logic within the `McpElicitationService`. The previous implementation incorrectly marked emails containing an '@' as invalid; this change corrects the logic to properly validate email addresses.

- Bug fix: Corrected the email validation in the `_validateStringFormat` method of `McpElicitationService` to ensure that values containing an '@' are now considered valid emails.

fixes #265325

body:

<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
-**Summary:**  
Submitting an MCP Elicitation Request with a field using schema `format: 'email'` results in an error when entering an email containing an `@`. The validation incorrectly rejects valid emails.

**VS Code Version:** 1.103.2  
**OS Version:** macOS Sequoia 15.6

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Initiate an MCP Elicitation Request.
2. In any field expecting an email (`format: 'email'`), enter a valid address (e.g., `user@example.com`).
3. Observe: As soon as an `@` is entered, an error message appears and the input is rejected.

**Expected Behavior:**  
Email addresses containing an `@` should be accepted as valid.

**Actual Behavior:**  
Emails with an `@` are erroneously rejected.

**Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?** Yes

**Additional Context:**  
- Verified with VS Code Insiders, issue persists with all extensions disabled.
- No external extensions are affecting validation.

labels.name: bug

labels.name: insiders-released

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->

<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: I need to use Github Copilot to reproduce this, so no?

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: Version: 1.104.0-insider (Universal) Commit: 70e7eae7709159b57b503df2541e0cb2e7b66c92
- OS Version: Mac OS 15.6.1

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Have an MCP server send multiple concurrent LLM sampling requests. If relevant, the server was implemented with fastmcp, but I think it's a thing in VSCode.
2. Observe that despite clicking "Always allow" (or other versions of allow) in the dialog, we still see as many dialogs as there are concurrent requests, which can be a lot.

Instead it would be better if only one dialog is shown, so if we always allow sampling requests, we don't spam user with such dialogs.

body: We currently only fire the `onDidRefetchAssignments` event when we use API to fetch the assignments from the experimentation platform. The TAS client re-fetches the assignments every hour, in these cases we do not fire the event. This will lead to invalid exp data sent.

title: Fix submenu overflow in TreeView when horizontal space is insufficient
body:
When the TreeView has insufficient horizontal width, context menu submenus would overflow and visually "pierce through" the container boundaries, extending past the VS Code window edge. This created layout issues and poor user experience in narrow workspace layouts.

The issue occurred in the `calculateSubmenuMenuLayout` method which didn't properly handle cases where the submenu would extend beyond the window boundaries. The existing logic only checked for overlap with the parent menu item but didn't ensure the submenu stayed within the viewport.

**Changes made:**

1. **Added boundary detection**: Check if the calculated submenu position would cause it to overflow past the right edge of the window
2. **Alternative positioning**: When overflow is detected, try positioning the submenu to the left of the parent menu item instead
3. **Fallback constraint**: If positioning to the left would also cause issues (submenu too wide), constrain the position to ensure it fits within the window bounds

**Implementation details:**

```typescript
// Ensure submenu doesn't overflow past the right edge of the window
if (ret.left + submenu.width > windowDimensions.width) {
    // Try positioning to the left of the parent menu item
    const leftPosition = entry.left - submenu.width;
    if (leftPosition >= 0) {
        ret.left = leftPosition;
    } else {
        // Constrain the submenu to fit within the window
        ret.left = Math.max(0, windowDimensions.width - submenu.width);
    }
}
```

This fix ensures submenus are always positioned within the visible viewport, preventing the visual piercing issue while maintaining proper menu functionality.

Fixes #263546.

title: Support passing VS Code conversation context via _meta

labels.name: insiders-released
labels.description: Patch has been released in VS Code Insiders

body:
I would like to propose using the _meta field defined in the [MCP specification](https://modelcontextprotocol.io/specification/2025-06-18/basic?utm_source=chatgpt.com#meta)
 to carry additional contextual information such as a VS Code conversation ID.

This would allow clients (e.g., VS Code extensions) to associate requests and responses with the correct conversation or session, improving traceability and enabling richer user experiences.

title: When WSL is closed / crashes, all open instances of VSCode have to be closed completely - reload window and attempting to reconnect fails
body:
Type: Bug * Open VSCode in WSL and have some files open, workspace or not does not seem to make a difference * simulate WSL crashing - `taskkill /f /IM wsl.exe` in command prompt with administration privileges * return to VSCode to observe it no longer has connection to WSL's filesystem through the host server * wait for the dialog to appear, asking to reconnect now or reload window * attempt both options and observe still no chips! (even after multiple attempts) * wait for IDE to appear (after reload attempt), toggle developer tools * hit F5 to refresh via the dev tool * observe the IDE now connects to the new WSL server (updated / corrected PID?) * session appears to be reinstated, albeit with a new instance of the server running (may have knock on effects) Note: bisect makes no difference The alternative is to kill "code.exe" in the same way as "wsl.exe" as mentioned above and start the session again. title: Expose command and context key to close Dirty Diff inline view
body: Currently, the "Dirty Diff" inline view (the zone widget that appears when using "Show Previous Change" on a modified line gutter) can only be closed by clicking the small "x" button with the mouse. Problem: - The Dirty Diff widget is not focusable from the editor using the keyboard (arrow keys or tab do not reach it). - There is no public command exposed to close it (`closeDirtyDiff` is not available in the command registry). - As a result, it's impossible to bind a keyboard shortcut (e.g. Escape) to close this view. Expected / Feature request: - Expose a command like `git.closeDirtyDiff`. - Provide a `when` context key (e.g. `dirtyDiffVisible`) that evaluates to `true` when the Dirty Diff widget is open. Benefits: - Keyboard users (or users with accessibility needs) would be able to close the Dirty Diff without touching the mouse. - Consistency with Peek editors, which already support both a command and a context key for closing. Steps to reproduce current limitation: 1. Open a file with uncommitted changes. 2. Click in the gutter and choose "Show Previous Change". 3. The Dirty Diff widget appears. 4. Press Escape → nothing happens, the widget remains open. 5. No command exists in the Command Palette or `keybindings.json` (to my knowledge ) to close it. This makes it impossible to close the widget using only the keyboard. ## Config ```text Version: 1.103.2 Commit: 6f17636121051a53c88d3e605c491d22af2ba755 Date: 2025-08-20T16:45:34.255Z Electron: 37.2.3 ElectronBuildId: 12035395 Chromium: 138.0.7204.100 Node.js: 22.17.0 V8: 13.8.500258-electron.0 OS: Darwin arm64 24.6.0 ```

title: Old Godot knowledge
body: Type: Bug Copilot keeps providing solutions based on old version of Godot Recent example: suggested to use `setget` keyword for setter/getter function combo, avaliable in Godot 3.6 https://docs.godotengine.org/en/3.6/tutorials/scripting/gdscript/gdscript_basics.html#setters-getters in Godot 4.x it's now separate `get` and `set` keywords https://docs.godotengine.org/en/stable/tutorials/scripting/gdscript/gdscript_basics.html#properties-setters-and-getters Used prompt: "when `my_origin` is set I want to call a setter function. title: Markdown preview doesn't refresh/reload when the file is overwritten
body: Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes - VS Code Version: 1.102.3 - OS Version: Microsoft Windows 11 Pro, 10.0.26100 Build 26100 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Generate a markdown file with some content 2. Open the markdown in VS Code and preview using the "Open Preview" button > Do not close the VS Code instance 3. Override the file from 1, may be by downloading/copying a markdown file with the same name. 4. Now open the new file in VS Code and preview the data 5. The preview from the earlier version of the file is shown and not the latest file

title: Fix task command line escaping and quoting for better shell compatibility
body:
This PR addresses issues with task command line escaping and quoting that were causing problems for extensions and users across different shell environments.

## Issues Fixed

**Double Quoting Problem (#260534):**
Extensions that manually quoted their commands were experiencing double-quoting issues where:
```
Expected: cmd.exe /C "unify_builder -p d:\MyProgram\xxx\builder.params"
Actual:   cmd.exe /C ""unify_builder -p d:\MyProgram\xxx\builder.params""
```

**Argument Separation and Escaping (#265274):**
Command arguments were not being properly separated and escaped, especially for PowerShell:
```
Expected: pwsh.exe "Q:\src\script.ps1" "arg number one" "arg`"two"
Actual:   pwsh.exe "Q:\src\script.ps1 'arg number one' arg\"two"
```

## Changes Made

### 1. Enhanced Quote Escaping
Improved the `quote` function to properly escape quote characters within argument values for different shell types:
- **PowerShell**: Uses backticks (`) to escape quotes within arguments
- **Bash**: Uses backslashes (\) to escape quotes within arguments
- **cmd.exe**: Handles quote escaping appropriately for Windows command prompt

### 2. Fixed cmd.exe Double-Wrapping Logic
Refined the cmd.exe command line wrapping logic to prevent unnecessary double-quoting:
- Only wraps the entire command line when it contains special characters (&, |, ^) that require it
- Avoids wrapping already quoted single commands with no arguments
- Maintains existing behavior for complex scenarios that legitimately need wrapping

### 3. Conservative Approach
Maintained the existing `needsQuotes` function logic to ensure backward compatibility while adding targeted improvements for the specific reported issues.

## Example Improvements

**Before:**
```typescript
// Extension code: commandLine = `"${commandLine}"`
// Result: cmd.exe /C ""my_command""  ❌ Double quoted
```

**After:**
```typescript
// Extension code: commandLine = `"${commandLine}"`  
// Result: cmd.exe /C "my_command"   ✅ Properly quoted
```

**PowerShell argument escaping:**
```typescript
// Before: script.ps1 'arg number one' arg"two
// After:  "script.ps1" "arg number one" "arg`"two"  ✅ Properly escaped
```

## Testing

The changes have been validated against the specific scenarios reported in the issues:
- Extensions providing pre-quoted commands no longer experience double-quoting
- Arguments with special characters are properly escaped for each shell type
- Complex cmd.exe scenarios still receive appropriate wrapping when needed
- Existing task configurations continue to work without modification

Fixes #265274.

title: Primary Sidebar Does Not Occupy Full Height Like Secondary Sidebar When Panel Is Open
body: Type: Feature Request When opening the bottom panel in VS Code, the display behavior of the left primary sidebar and the right secondary sidebar is inconsistent. The primary sidebar does not occupy the full height of the column, while the secondary sidebar does. Shouldn't these two sidebars behave consistently, or at least provide a configuration option to modify their display style? VS Code version: Code - Insiders 1.104.0-insider (7be2a0b2e60c47a0dbd586fc56b64b55e03bd954, 2025-09-04T20:16:36.013Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 Modes:

title: Cengage learning link not showing up

labels.name: *caused-by-extension
labels.description: Issue identified to be caused by an extension

body: Cengage thats linked to my school for assignments are not showing up in the left panelpane as others. How can I correct this so I'm allowed to turn in my assignments?
